verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:1
verses.text: Homily II.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:2
verses.text: After Eutropius having been found outside the Church had been taken captive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:3
verses.text: Delectable indeed are the meadow, and the garden, but far more delectable the study of the divine writings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:4
verses.text: For there indeed are flowers which fade, but here are thoughts which abide in full bloom; there is the breeze of the zephyr, but here the breath of the Spirit: there is the hedge of thorns, but here is the guarding providence of God; there is the song of cicadae, but here the melody of the prophets: there is the pleasure which comes from sight, but here the profit which comes from study.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:5
verses.text: The garden is confined to one place, but the Scriptures are in all parts of the world; the garden is subject to the necessities of the seasons, but the Scriptures are rich in foliage, and laden with fruit alike in winter and in summer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:6
verses.text: Let us then give diligent heed to the study of the Scriptures: for if thou doest this the Scripture will expel thy despondency, and engender pleasure, extirpate vice, and make virtue take root, and in the tumult of life it will save thee from suffering like those who are tossed by troubled waves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:7
verses.text: The sea rages but thou sailest on with calm weather; for thou hast the study of the Scriptures for thy pilot; for this is the cable which the trials of life do not break asunder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:8
verses.text: Now that I lie not events themselves bear witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:9
verses.text: A few days ago the Church was besieged: an army came, and fire issued from their eyes, yet it did not scorch the olive tree; swords were unsheathed, yet no one received a wound; the imperial gates were in distress, but the Church was in security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:10
verses.text: And yet the tide of war flowed hither; for here the refugee was sought, and we withstood them, not fearing their rage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:11
verses.text: And wherefore prithee? because we held as a sure pledge the saying "Thou art Peter, and upon this rock I will build my Church: and the gates of hell shall not prevail against it".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:12
verses.text: And when I say the Church I mean not only a place but also a plan of life: I mean not the walls of the Church but the laws of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:13
verses.text: When thou takest refuge in a Church, do not seek shelter merely in the place but in the spirit of the place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:14
verses.text: For the Church is not wall and roof but faith and life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:15
verses.text: Do not tell me that the man having been surrendered was surrendered by the Church; if he had not abandoned the Church he would not have been surrendered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:16
verses.text: Do not say that he fled here for refuge and then was given up: the Church did not abandon him but he abandoned the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:17
verses.text: He was not surrendered from within the Church but outside its walls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:18
verses.text: Wherefore did he forsake the Church? Didst thou desire to save thyself? Thou shouldst have held fast to the altar.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:19
verses.text: There were no walls here, but there was the guarding providence of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:20
verses.text: Wast thou a sinner? God does not reject thee: for "He came not to call the righteous but sinners to repentance".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:21
verses.text: The harlot was saved when she clung to His feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:22
verses.text: Have ye heard the passage read to-day? Now I say these things that thou mayest not hesitate to take refuge in the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:23
verses.text: Abide with the Church, and the Church does not hand thee over to the enemy: but if thou fliest from the Church, the Church is not the cause of thy capture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:24
verses.text: For if thou art inside the fold the wolf does not enter: but if thou goest outside, thou art liable to be the wild beast's prey: yet this is not the fault of the fold, but of thy own pusillanimity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:25
verses.text: The Church hath no feet.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:26
verses.text: Talk not to me of walls and arms: for walls wax old with time, but the Church has no old age.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:27
verses.text: Walls are shattered by barbarians, but over the Church even demons do not prevail.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:28
verses.text: And that my words are no mere vaunt there is the evidence of facts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:29
verses.text: How many have assailed the Church, and yet the assailants have perished while the Church herself has soared beyond the sky? Such might hath the Church: when she is assailed she conquers: when snares are laid for her she prevails: when she is insulted her prosperity increases: she is wounded yet sinks not under her wounds; tossed by waves yet not submerged; vexed by storms yet suffers no shipwreck; she wrestles and is not worsted, fights but is not vanquished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:30
verses.text: Wherefore then did she suffer this war to be? That she might make more manifest the splendour of her triumph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:31
verses.text: Ye were present on that day, and ye saw what weapons were set in motion against her, and how the rage of the soldiers burned more fiercely than fire, and I was hurried away to the imperial palace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:32
verses.text: But what of that? By the grace of God none of those things dismayed me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:33
verses.text: Now I say these things in order that ye too may follow my example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:34
verses.text: But wherefore was I not dismayed? Because I do not fear any present terrors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:35
verses.text: For what is terrible? Death? nay this is not terrible: for we speedily reach the unruffled haven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:36
verses.text: Or spoliation of goods? "Naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I depart;" or exile? "The earth is the Lord's and the fulness thereof;" or false accusation? "Rejoice and be exceeding glad, when men shall say all manner of evil against you falsely, for great is your reward in Heaven".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:37
verses.text: I saw the swords and I meditated on Heaven; I expected death, and I bethought me of the resurrection; I beheld the sufferings of this lower world, and I took account of the heavenly prizes; I observed the devices of the enemy, and I meditated on the heavenly crown: for the occasion of the contest was sufficient for encouragement and consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:38
verses.text: True! I was being forcibly dragged away, but I suffered no insult from the act; for there is only one real insult, namely sin: and should the whole world insult thee, yet if thou dost not insult thyself thou art not insulted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:39
verses.text: The only real betrayal is the betrayal of the conscience: betray not thy own conscience, and no one can betray thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:40
verses.text: I was being dragged away and I saw the eventsâ€”or rather I saw my words turned into events, I saw my discourse which I had uttered in words being preached in the market-place through the medium of actual events.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:41
verses.text: What kind of discourse? the same which I was always repeating.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:42
verses.text: The wind has blown and the leaves have fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:43
verses.text: "The grass has withered and the flower has faded".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:44
verses.text: The night has departed and the day has dawned; the shadow has been proved vain and the truth has appeared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:45
verses.text: They mounted up to the sky, and they came down to the level of earth: for the waves which were swelling high have been laid low by means of merely human events.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:46
verses.text: How? The things which were taking place were a lesson.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:47
verses.text: And I said to myself will posterity learn self-control? or before two days have passed by will these events have been abandoned to oblivion? The warnings were sounding in their ears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:48
verses.text: Again let me utter, yet again I will speak.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:49
verses.text: What profit will there be? Certainly there will be profit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:50
verses.text: For if all do not hearken, the half will hearken; and if not the half, the third part: and if not the third the fourth: and if not the fourth, perhaps ten: and if not ten, perhaps five: and if not five perhaps one: and if not one, I myself have the reward prepared for me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:51
verses.text: "The grass withereth and the flower fadeth; but the word of God abideth for ever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:52
verses.text: Have ye seen the insignificance of human affairs? have ye seen the frailty of power? Have ye seen the wealth which I always called a runaway and not a runaway only, but also a murderer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:53
verses.text: For it not only deserts those who possess it, but also slaughters them; for when any one pays court to it then most of all does it betray him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:54
verses.text: Why dost thou pay court to wealth which to-day is for thee, and to-morrow for another? Why dost thou court wealth which can never be held fast? Dost thou desire to court it? dost thou desire to hold it fast? Do not bury it but give it into the hands of the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:55
verses.text: For wealth is a wild beast: if it be tightly held it runs away: if it be let loose it remains where it is; "For," it is said, "he hath dispersed abroad and given to the poor; his righteousness remaineth forever".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:56
verses.text: Disperse it then that it may remain with thee; bury it not lest it run away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:57
verses.text: Where is wealth? I would gladly enquire of those who have departed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:58
verses.text: Now I say these things not by way of reproach, God forbid, nor by way of irritating old sores, but as endeavouring to secure a haven for you out of the shipwreck of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:59
verses.text: When soldiers and swords were threatening, when the city was in a blaze of fury, when the imperial majesty was powerless, and the purple was insulted, when all places were full of frenzy, where was wealth then? where was your silver plate? where were your silver couches? where your household slaves? they had all betaken themselves to flight; where were the eunuchs? they all ran away; where were your friends? they changed their masks.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:60
verses.text: Where were your houses? they were shut up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:61
verses.text: Where was your money? the owner of it fled: and the money itself, where was that? it was buried.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:62
verses.text: Where was it all hidden? Am I oppressive and irksome to you in constantly declaring that wealth betrays those who use it badly? The occasion has now come which proves the truth of my words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:63
verses.text: Why dost thou hold it so tightly, when in the time of trial it profiteth thee nothing? If it has power when thou fallest into a strait, let it come to thy aid, but if it then runs away what need hast thou of it? events themselves bear witness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:64
verses.text: What profit was there in it? The sword was whetted, death was impending, an army raging: there was apprehension of imminent peril; and yet wealth was nowhere to be seen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:65
verses.text: Where did the runaway flee? It was itself the cause which brought about all these evils, and yet in the hours of necessity it runs away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:66
verses.text: Nevertheless many reproach me saying continually thou fasteneth upon the rich: while they on the other hand fasten upon the poor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:67
verses.text: Well I do fasten upon the rich: or rather not the rich, but those who make a bad use of their riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:68
verses.text: For I am continually saying that I do not attack the character of the rich man, but of the rapacious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:69
verses.text: A rich man is one thing, a rapacious man is another: an affluent man is one thing, a covetous man is another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:70
verses.text: Make clear distinctions, and do not confuse things which are diverse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:71
verses.text: Art thou a rich man? I forbid thee not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:72
verses.text: Art thou a rapacious man? I denounce thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:73
verses.text: Hast thou property of thy own? enjoy it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:74
verses.text: Dost thou take the property of others? I will not hold my peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:75
verses.text: Wouldest thou stone me for this? I am ready to shed my blood: only I forbid thy sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:76
verses.text: I heed not hatred, I heed not war: one thing only do I heed, the advancement of my hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:77
verses.text: The rich are my children, and the poor also are my children: the same womb has travailed with both, both are the offspring of the same travail-pangs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:78
verses.text: If then thou fastenest reproaches on the poor man, I denounce thee: for the poor man does not suffer so much loss as the rich.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:79
verses.text: For no great wrong is inflicted on the poor man, seeing that in his case the injury is confined to money; but in thy case the injury touches the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:80
verses.text: Let him who wills cast me off, let him who wills stone me, let him who wills hate me: for the plots of enemies are the pledges to me of crowns of victory, and the number of my rewards will be as the number of my wounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:81
verses.text: So then I fear not an enemy's plots: one thing only do I fear, which is sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:82
verses.text: If no one convicts me of sin, then let the whole world make war upon me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:83
verses.text: For this kind of war only renders me more prosperous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:84
verses.text: Thus also do I wish to teach you a lesson.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:85
verses.text: Fear not the devices of a potentate, but fear the power of sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:86
verses.text: No man will do thee harm, if thou dost not deal a blow to thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:87
verses.text: If thou hast not sin, ten thousand swords may threaten thee, but God will snatch thee away out of their reach: but if thou hast sin, even shouldest thou be in paradise thou wilt be cast out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:88
verses.text: Adam was in paradise yet he fell; Job was on a dung hill, yet he was crowned victorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:89
verses.text: What profit was paradise to the one? or what injury was the dung hill to the other? No man laid snares for the one, yet was he overthrown: the devil laid snares for the other, and yet he was crowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:90
verses.text: Did not the devil take his property? Yes, but he did not rob him of his godliness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:91
verses.text: Did he not lay violent hands upon his sons? yes: but he did not shake his faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:92
verses.text: Did he not tear his body to pieces? yes but he did not find his treasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:93
verses.text: Did he not arm his wife against him? yes but he did not overthrow the soldier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:94
verses.text: Did he not hurl arrows and darts at him? yes but he received no wounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:95
verses.text: He advanced his engines but could not shake the tower; he conducted his billows against him, but did not sink the ship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:96
verses.text: Observe this law I beseech you, yea I clasp your knees, if not with the bodily hand, yet in spirit, and pour forth tears of supplication.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:97
verses.text: Observe this law I pray you, and no one can do you harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:98
verses.text: Never call the rich man happy; never call any man miserable save him who is living in sin: and call him happy who lives in righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:99
verses.text: For it is not the nature of their circumstances, but the disposition of the men which makes both the one and the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:100
verses.text: Never be afraid of the sword if thy conscience does not accuse thee: never be afraid in war if thy conscience is clear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:101
verses.text: Where are they who have departed? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:102
verses.text: Did not all men once bow down to them? did not those who were in authority tremble greatly before them? did they not pay court to them? But sin has come, and all things are manifested in their true lights; they who were attendants have become judges, the flatterers are turned into executioners; they who once kissed his hands, dragged him themselves from the church, and he who yesterday kissed his hand is to-day his enemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:103
verses.text: Wherefore? Because neither did he yesterday love him with sincerity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:104
verses.text: For the opportunity came and the actors were unmasked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:105
verses.text: Didst thou not yesterday kiss his hands, and call him saviour, and guardian, and benefactor? Didst thou not compose panegyrics without end? wherefore to-day dost thou accuse him? Why yesterday a praiser, and to-day an accuser? why yesterday utter panegyrics, and to-day reproaches? What means this change? what means this revolution?.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:106
verses.text: But I am not like this: I was the subject of his plots, yet I became his protector.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:107
verses.text: I suffered countless troubles at his hands, yet I did not retaliate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:108
verses.text: For I copy the example of my Master, who said on the cross, "Forgive them, for they know not what they do".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:109
verses.text: Now I say these things that you may not be perverted by the suspicion of wicked men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:110
verses.text: Now many changes have taken place, since I had the oversight of the city, and yet no one learns self-control? But when I say no one, I do not condemn all, God forbid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:111
verses.text: For it is impossible that this rich soil when it has received seed, should not produce one ear of corn: but I am insatiable, I do not wish many to be saved but all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:112
verses.text: And if but one be left in a perishing condition, I perish also, and deem that the Shepherd should be imitated who had ninety-nine sheep, and yet hastened after the one which had gone astray.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:113
verses.text: How long will money last? how long this silver and gold? how long these draughts of wine? how long the flatteries of slaves? how long these goblets wreathed with garlands? how long these satanic drinking feasts, full of diabolical activity?  Dost thou not know that the present life is a sojourn in a far country? for art thou a citizen? Nay thou art a wayfarer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:114
verses.text: Understandest thou what I say? Thou art not a citizen, but thou art a wayfarer, and a traveller.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:115
verses.text: Say not: I have this city and that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:116
verses.text: No one has a city.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:117
verses.text: The city is above.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:118
verses.text: Present life is but a journey.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:119
verses.text: We are journeying on every day, while nature is running its course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:120
verses.text: Some there are who store up goods on the way: some who bury jewellery on the road.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:121
verses.text: Now when you enter an inn do you beautify the inn? not so, but you eat and drink and hasten to depart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:122
verses.text: The present life is an inn: we have entered it, and we bring present life to a close: let us be eager to depart with a good hope, let us leave nothing here, that we may not lose it there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:123
verses.text: When you enter the inn, what do you say to the servant? Take care where you put away our things, that you do not leave anything behind here, that nothing may be lost, not even what is small and trifling, in order that we may carry everything back to our home.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:124
verses.text: Thou art a wayfarer and traveller, and indeed more insignificant than the wayfarer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:125
verses.text: How so? I will tell you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:126
verses.text: The wayfarer knows when he is going into the inn, and when he is going out; for the egress as well as the regress is in his own power: but when I enter the inn, that is to say this present life, I know not when I shall go out: and it may be that I am providing myself with sustenance for a long time when the Master suddenly summons me saying "Thou fool, for whom shall those things be which thou hast prepared? for on this very night thy soul is being taken from thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:127
verses.text: The time of thy departure is uncertain, the tenure of thy possessions insecure, there are innumerable precipices, and billows on every side of thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:128
verses.text: Why dost thou rave about shadows? why desert the reality and run after shadows?.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:129
verses.text: I say these things, and shall not cease saying them, causing continual pain, and dressing the wounds; and this not for the sake of the fallen, but of those who are still standing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:130
verses.text: For they have departed, and their career is ended, but those who are yet standing have gained a more secure position through their calamities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:131
verses.text: "What then," you say, "shall we do?" Do one thing only, hate riches, and love thy lifeâ€”cast away thy goods; I do not say all of them, but cut off the superfluities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:132
verses.text: Be not covetous of other men's goods, strip not the widow, plunder not the orphan, seize not his house: I do not address myself to persons but to facts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:133
verses.text: But if any one's conscience attacks him, he himself is responsible for it, not my words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:134
verses.text: Why art thou grasping where thou bringest ill-will upon thyself? Grasp where there is a crown to be gained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:135
verses.text: Strive to lay hold not of earth but of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:136
verses.text: "The kingdom of Heaven belongs to violent men and men of violence take it by force".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:137
verses.text: Why dost thou lay hold of the poor man who reproaches thee? Lay hold of Christ who praises thee for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:138
verses.text: Dost thou see thy senselessness and madness? Dost thou lay hold of the poor man who has little? Christ says "lay hold of me; I thank thee for it, lay hold of my kingdom and take it by violence".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:139
verses.text: If thou art minded to lay hold of an earthly kingdom, or rather if thou art minded to have designs upon it thou art punished; but in the case of the heavenly kingdom thou art punished if thou dost not lay hold of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:140
verses.text: Where worldly things are concerned there is ill-will, but where spiritual there is love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:141
verses.text: Meditate daily on these things, and if two days hence thou seest another riding in a chariot, arrayed in raiment of silk, and elated with pride, be not again dismayed and troubled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:142
verses.text: Praise not a rich man, but only him who lives in righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:143
verses.text: Revile not a poor man, but learn to have an upright and accurate judgment in all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:144
verses.text: Do not hold aloof from the Church; for nothing is stronger than the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:145
verses.text: The Church is thy hope, thy salvation, thy refuge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:146
verses.text: It is higher than the heaven, it is wider than the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:147
verses.text: It never waxes old, but is always in full vigour.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:148
verses.text: Wherefore as significant of its solidity and stability Holy Scripture calls it a mountain: or of its purity a virgin, or of its magnificence a queen; or of its relationship to God a daughter; and to express its productiveness it calls her barren who has borne seven: in fact it employs countless names to represent its nobleness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:149
verses.text: For as the master of the Church has many names: being called the Father, and the way, and the life, and the light, and the arm, and the propitiation, and the foundation, and the door, and the sinless one, and the treasure, and Lord, and God, and Son, and the only begotten, and the form of God, and the image of God so is it with the Church itself: does one name suffice to present the whole truth? by no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:150
verses.text: But for this reason there are countless names, that we may learn something concerning God, though it be but a small part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:151
verses.text: Even so the Church also is called by many names.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:152
verses.text: She is called a virgin, albeit formerly she was an harlot: for this is the miracle wrought by the Bridegroom, that He took her who was an harlot and hath made her a virgin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:153
verses.text: Oh! what a new and strange event! With us marriage destroys virginity, but with God marriage hath restored it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:154
verses.text: With us she who is a virgin, when married, is a virgin no longer: with Christ she who is an harlot, when married, becomes a virgin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:155
verses.text: Let the heretic who inquires curiously into the nature of heavenly generation saying "how did the Father beget the Son?" interpret this single fact, ask him how did the Church, being an harlot, become a virgin? and how did she having brought forth children remain a virgin? "For I am jealous over you," saith Paul, "with a godly jealousy, for I espoused you to one husband that I might present you as a pure virgin to Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:156
verses.text: What wisdom and understanding! "I am jealous over you with a godly jealousy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:157
verses.text: What means this? "I am jealous," he says: art thou jealous seeing thou art a spiritual man? I am jealous he says as God is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:158
verses.text: And hath God jealousy? yea the jealousy not of passion, but of love, and earnest zeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:159
verses.text: I am jealous over you with the jealousy of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:160
verses.text: Shall I tell thee how He manifests His jealousy? He saw the world corrupted by devils, and He delivered His own Son to save it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:161
verses.text: For words spoken in reference to God have not the same force as when spoken in reference to ourselves: for instance we say God is jealous, God is wroth, God repents, God hates.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:162
verses.text: These words are human, but they have a meaning which becomes the nature of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:163
verses.text: How is God jealous? "I am jealous over you with the jealousy of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:164
verses.text: Is God wroth? "O Lord reproach me not in thine indignation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:165
verses.text: Doth God slumber? "Awake, wherefore sleepest thou, O Lord?" Doth God repent? "I repent that I have made man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:166
verses.text: Doth God hate? "My soul hateth your feasts and your new moons".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:167
verses.text: Well do not consider the poverty of the expressions: but grasp their divine meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:168
verses.text: God is jealous, for He loves, God is wroth, not as yielding to passion, but for the purpose of chastising, and punishing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:169
verses.text: God sleeps, not as really slumbering, but as being long-suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:170
verses.text: Choose out the expression.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:171
verses.text: Thus when thou hearest that God begets the Son, think not of division but of the unity of substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:172
verses.text: For God has taken many of these words from us as we also have borrowed others from Him, that we may receive honour thereby.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:173
verses.text: Dost thou understand what I have said? Attend carefully my beloved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:174
verses.text: There are divine names, and there are human names.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:175
verses.text: God has received from me, and He Himself hath given to me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:176
verses.text: Give me thine, and take mine He says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:177
verses.text: Thou hast need of mine: I have no need of thine, but thou hast of mine inasmuch as my nature is unmixed, but thou art a human being encompassed with a body, seeking also corporeal terms in order that, by borrowing expressions which are familiar to thee, thou who art thus encompassed with a body, mayest be able to think on thoughts which transcend thy understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:178
verses.text: What kind of names hath He received from me, and what kind hath He given to me? He Himself is God, and He hath called me God; with Him is the essential nature as an actual fact, with me only the honour of the name: "I have said ye are gods, and ye are all children of the most highest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:179
verses.text: Here are words, but in the other case there is the actual reality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:180
verses.text: He hath called me god, for by that name I have received honour.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:181
verses.text: He Himself was called man, he was called Son of man, he was called the Way, the Door, the Rock.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:182
verses.text: These words He borrowed from me; the others He gave from Himself to me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:183
verses.text: Wherefore was He called the Way? That thou mightest understand that by Him we have access to the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:184
verses.text: Wherefore was He called the Rock? that thou mightest understand the secure and unshaken character of the faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:185
verses.text: Wherefore was He called the Foundation? That thou mightest understand that He upholdeth all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:186
verses.text: Wherefore was He called the Root? That thou mightest understand that in Him we have our power of growth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:187
verses.text: Wherefore was He called the Shepherd? Because He feeds us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:188
verses.text: Wherefore was He called a sheep? Because He was sacrificed for us and became a propitiatory offering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:189
verses.text: Wherefore was He called the Life? Because He raised us up when we were dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:190
verses.text: Wherefore was He called the Light? Because He delivered us from darkness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:191
verses.text: Why was He called an Arm? Because He is of one substance with the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:192
verses.text: Why was He called the Word? Because He was begotten of the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:193
verses.text: For as my word is the offspring of my spirit, even so was the Son begotten of the Father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:194
verses.text: Wherefore is He called our raiment? Because I was clothed with Him when I was baptized.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:195
verses.text: Why is He called a table? Because I feed upon Him when I partake of the mysteries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:196
verses.text: Why is He called a house? Because I dwell in Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:197
verses.text: Why is He called an inmate of the house? Because we become His Temple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:198
verses.text: Wherefore is He called the Head? Because I have been made a member of His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:199
verses.text: Why is He called a Bridegroom? Because He hath taken me as His bride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:200
verses.text: Wherefore is He called undefiled? Because He took me as a virgin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:201
verses.text: Wherefore is He called Master? Because I am His bondmaid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:202
verses.text: For observe the Church, how, as I was saying, she is sometimes a bride, sometimes a daughter, sometimes a virgin, sometimes a bondmaid, sometimes a queen, sometimes a barren woman, sometimes a mountain, sometimes a garden, sometimes fruitful in children, sometimes a lily, sometimes a fountain: She is all things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:203
verses.text: Therefore having heard these things, think not I pray you that they are corporeal; but stretch thy thought further: for such things cannot be corporeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:204
verses.text: For example: the mountain is not the maid: the maid is not the bride: the queen is not the bond-maid: yet the Church is all these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:205
verses.text: Wherefore? because the element in which they exist is not corporeal but spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:206
verses.text: For in a corporeal sphere these things are confined within narrow limits: but in a spiritual sphere they have a wide field of operation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:207
verses.text: "The queen stood on thy right hand".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:208
verses.text: The queen? How did she who was down-trodden and poor become a queen? and where did she ascend? the queen herself stood on high by the side of the king.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:209
verses.text: How? because the king became a servant; He was not that by nature, but He became so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:210
verses.text: Understand therefore the things which belong to the Godhead, and discern those which belong to the Dispensation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:211
verses.text: Understand what He was, and what He became for thy sake, and do not confuse things which are distinct, nor make the argument of his lovingkindness an occasion for blasphemy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:212
verses.text: He was lofty, and she was lowly: lofty not by position but by nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:213
verses.text: His essence was pure, and imperishable: His nature was incorruptible, unintelligible, invisible, incomprehensible, eternal, unchangeable, transcending the nature of angels, higher than the powers above, overpowering reason, surpassing thought, apprehended not by sight but by faith alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:214
verses.text: Angels beheld Him and trembled, the Cherubim veiled themselves with their wings, in awe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:215
verses.text: He looked upon the earth, and caused it to tremble: He threatened the sea and dried it up: he brought rivers out of the desert: He weighed the mountains in scales, and the valleys in a balance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:216
verses.text: How shall I express myself? how shall I present the truth? His greatness hath no bounds, His wisdom is beyond reckoning, His judgments are untraceable, His ways unsearchable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:217
verses.text: Such is His greatness and His power, if indeed it is safe even to use such expressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:218
verses.text: But what am I to do? I am a human being and I speak in human language: my tongue is of earth and I crave forgiveness from my Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:219
verses.text: For I do not use these expressions in a spirit of presumption, but on account of the poverty of my resources arising from my feebleness and the nature of our human tongue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:220
verses.text: Be merciful to me, O Lord, for I utter these words not in presumption but because I have no others: nevertheless I do not rest content with the meanness of my speech, but soar upwards on the wings of my understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:221
verses.text: Such is His greatness and power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:222
verses.text: I say this, that without dwelling on the words, or on the poverty of the expressions, thou mayest also thyself learn to act in the same way.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:223
verses.text: Why dost thou marvel if I do this, inasmuch as He also does the same, when He wishes to present something to our minds which transcends human powers? Since He addresses human beings He uses also human illustration, which are indeed insufficient to represent the thing spoken of, and cannot exhibit the full proportions of the matter, yet suffice for the infirmity of the hearers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:224
verses.text: Make an effort, and do not grow weary of my prolonged discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:225
verses.text: For as when He manifests Himself, He is not manifested as He really is, nor is His bare essence manifested (for no man hath seen God in His real nature; for when He is but partially revealed the Cherubim trembleâ€”the mountains smoke, the sea is dried up, the heaven is shaken, and if the revelation were not partial who could endure it?) as then, I say, He does not manifest Himself as He really is, but only as the beholder is able to see Him, therefore doth He appear sometimes in the form of old age, sometimes of youth, sometimes in fire, sometimes in air, sometimes in water, sometimes in armour, not altering his essential nature, but fashioning His appearance to suit the various condition of those who are affected by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:226
verses.text: In like manner also when any one wishes to say anything concerning Him he employs human illustrations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:227
verses.text: For instance I say: "He went up into the mountain and He was transfigured before them, and His countenance shone as the sun, and His raiment became white as snow".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:228
verses.text: He disclosed, it is said, a little of the Godhead, He manifested to them the God dwelling amongst them "and He was transfigured before them".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:229
verses.text: Attend carefully to the statement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:230
verses.text: The writer says and He was transfigured before them, and His raiment shone as the light, and His countenance was as the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:231
verses.text: When I said "such is His greatness and power" and added "be merciful to me O Lord," (for I do not rest satisfied with the expression but am perplexed, having no other framed for the purpose) I wish you to understand, that I learned this lesson from Holy Scripture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:232
verses.text: The evangelist then wished to describe His splendour and he says "He shone".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:233
verses.text: How did He shine? tell me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:234
verses.text: Exceedingly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:235
verses.text: And how do you express this? He shone "as the sun".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:236
verses.text: As the sun sayest thou? Yea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:237
verses.text: Wherefore? Because I know not any other luminary more brilliant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:238
verses.text: And He was white sayest thou as snow? wherefore as snow? Because I know not any other substance which is whiter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:239
verses.text: For that He did not really shine thus is proved by what follows: the disciples fell to the ground.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:240
verses.text: If he had shone as the sun the disciples would not have fallen; for they saw the sun every day, and did not fall: but inasmuch as he shone more brilliantly than the sun or snow, they, being unable to bear the splendour, fell to the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:241
verses.text: Tell me then, O evangelist, did He shine more brightly than the sun, and yet dost thou say, "as the sun?" Yea: wishing to make that light known to thee, I know not any other greater luminary, I have no other comparison which holds a royal place amongst luminaries.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:242
verses.text: I have said these things that thou mayest not rest contentedly in the poverty of the language used: I have pointed out to thee the fall of the disciples: they fell to the earth, and were stupified and overwhelmed with slumber.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:243
verses.text: "Arise" He said, and lifted them up, and yet they were oppressed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:244
verses.text: For they could not endure the excessive brightness of that shining, but heavy sleep took possession of their eyes: so far did the light which was manifested exceed the light of the sun.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:245
verses.text: Yet the evangelist said "as the sun," because that luminary is familiar to us and surpasses all the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:246
verses.text: But as I was saying, He who was thus great and powerful desired an harlot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:247
verses.text: I speak of our human nature under that name.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:248
verses.text: If a man indeed desire an harlot he is condemned, and doth God desire one? Yea verily.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:249
verses.text: Again a man desireth an harlot that he may become a fornicator: but God that He may convert the harlot into a virgin: so that the desire of the man is the destruction of her who is desired: but the desire of God is salvation to her who is desired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:250
verses.text: And why did He who is so great and powerful desire an harlot? that He might become the husband thereof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:251
verses.text: How doth He act? He doth not send to her any of His servants, He sendeth not angel, archangel, Cherubim, or Seraphim; but He himself draws nigh Who loves her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:252
verses.text: Again when thou hearest of love, deem it not sensuous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:253
verses.text: Cull out the thoughts which are contained in the words, even as an excellent bee settles on the flowers, and takes the honey comb, but leaves the herbs God desired an harlot, and how doth He act? He does not conduct her on high; for He would not bring an harlot into Heaven, but He Himself comes down.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:254
verses.text: Since she could not ascend on high, He descends to earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:255
verses.text: He cometh to the harlot, and is not ashamed: He cometh to her secret dwelling place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:256
verses.text: He beholds her in her drunkenness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:257
verses.text: And how doth He come? not in the bare essence of His original nature, but He becomes that which the harlot was, not in intention but in reality does He become this, in order that she may not be scared when she sees Him, that she may not rush away, and escape.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:258
verses.text: He cometh to the harlot, and becomes man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:259
verses.text: And how does He become this? He is conceived in the womb, he increases little by little and follows like me the course of human growth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:260
verses.text: Who is it who does this? the Deity as manifested, not the Godhead; the form of the servant not that of the Master; the flesh which belongs to me, not the essential nature which belongs to Him: He increases little by little, and has intercourse with mankind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:261
verses.text: Although He finds the harlot, human nature, full of sores, brutalised, and oppressed by devils, how does He act? He draws nigh to her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:262
verses.text: She sees Him and flees away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:263
verses.text: He calleth the wise men saying Why are ye afraid? I am not a judge, but a physician.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:264
verses.text: "I came not to judge the world but to save the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:265
verses.text: Straightway He calleth the wise men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:266
verses.text: Oh! new and strange event.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:267
verses.text: The immediate first-fruits of His coming are wise men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:268
verses.text: He who upholds the world lieth in a manger, and He who careth for all things is a nursling in swaddling bands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:269
verses.text: The temple is founded and the God dwelleth therein.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:270
verses.text: And wise men come and straightway worship Him: the publican comes and is turned into an evangelist: the harlot comes and is turned into a maiden: the Canaanitish woman comes and partakes of his lovingkindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:271
verses.text: This is the mark of one who loves, to forbear demanding an account of sins, and to forgive transgressions and offences.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:272
verses.text: And how does He act? He takes the sinner and espouses her to himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:273
verses.text: And what doth He give her? a signet ring.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:274
verses.text: Of what nature? the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:275
verses.text: Paul saith "now He who establisheth us with you is God who hath also sealed us, and given the earnest of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:276
verses.text: The Spirit then He giveth her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:277
verses.text: Next He saith "Did not I plant thee in a garden?" She saith "yea".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:278
verses.text: And how didst thou fall from thence? "The devil came and cast me out of the garden".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:279
verses.text: Thou wast planted in the garden and he cast thee out: behold I plant thee in myself, I uphold thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:280
verses.text: How? The devil dares not approach me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:281
verses.text: Neither do I take thee up into Heaven; but something greater than Heaven is here: I carry thee in myself who am the Lord of Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:282
verses.text: The shepherd carries thee and the wolf no longer comes: or rather I permit him to approach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:283
verses.text: And so the Lord carrieth our nature: and the devil approaches and is worsted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:284
verses.text: "I have planted thee in myself:" therefore He saith "I am the root, ye are the branches:" so He planted her in Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:285
verses.text: "But," she saith, "I am a sinner and unclean".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:286
verses.text: "Let not this trouble thee, I am a physician.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:287
verses.text: I know my vessel, I know how it was perverted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:288
verses.text: It was formerly a vessel of clay, and it was perverted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:289
verses.text: I remodel it by means of the laver of regeneration and I submit it to the action of fire".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:290
verses.text: For observe: He took dust from the earth and made the man; He formed him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:291
verses.text: The devil came, and perverted him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:292
verses.text: Then the Lord came, took him again, and remoulded, and recast him in baptism, and He suffered not his body to be of clay, but made it of a harder ware.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:293
verses.text: He subjected the soft clay to the fire of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:294
verses.text: "He shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost and with fire:" He was baptized with water that he might be remodelled, with fire that he might be hardened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:295
verses.text: Therefore the Prophet speaking beforehand under divine guidance declared "Thou shalt dash them in pieces like vessels of the potter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:296
verses.text: He did not say like vessels of earthenware which every one possesses: for by a potter's vessels are meant those which the potter is fashioning on the wheel: now the potter's vessels are of clay, but ours are of harder ware.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:297
verses.text: Speaking beforehand therefore of the remoulding which is wrought by means of baptism he saith, "thou shalt dash them in pieces like vessels of a potter"â€”He means that He remodels and recasts them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:298
verses.text: I descend into the water of baptism, and the fashion of my nature is remoulded, and the fire of the Spirit recasts it, and it is turned into a harder ware.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:299
verses.text: And that my words are no empty vaunt hear what Job says, "He hath made us as clay," and Paul, "but we have this treasure in earthen vessels".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:300
verses.text: But consider the strength of the earthen vessel: for it has been hardened not by fire, but by the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:301
verses.text: How was it proved to be an earthen vessel? "Five times received I forty stripes save one, thrice was I beaten with rods, once was I stoned," and yet the earthen vessel was not shattered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:302
verses.text: "A day and a night have I been in the deep".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:303
verses.text: He hath been in the deep, and the earthen vessel was not dissolved: he suffered shipwreck and the treasure was not lost; the ship was submerged and yet the freight floated.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:304
verses.text: "But we have this treasure" he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:305
verses.text: What kind of treasure? a supply of the Spirit, righteousness, sanctification, redemption.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:306
verses.text: Of what nature, tell me? "in the name of Jesus Christ rise up and walk".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:307
verses.text: "aeneas, Jesus Christ maketh thee whole," I say unto thee thou evil spirit, go out of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:308
verses.text: Hast thou seen a treasure more brilliant than royal treasures? For what can the pearl of a king do like that which the words of an Apostle effected? Set crowns innumerable upon dead men, and they will not be raised: but one word went forth from an Apostle, and it brought back revoked nature, and restored it to its ancient condition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:309
verses.text: "But we have this treasure".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:310
verses.text: O treasure which not only is preserved, but also preserves the house where it is stored up.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:311
verses.text: Dost thou understand what I have said? The kings of the earth, and rulers when they have treasures, prepare large houses, having strong walls, bars, doors, guards, and bolts in order that the treasure may be preserved: but Christ did the contrary: He placed the treasure not in a stone vessel but in an earthen one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:312
verses.text: If the treasure is great wherefore is the vessel weak? But the reason why the vessel is weak is not because the treasure is great; for this is not preserved by the vessel, but itself preserves the vessel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:313
verses.text: I deposit the treasure: who is able henceforth to steal it? The devil has come, the world has come, multitudes have come, and yet they have not stolen the treasure: the vessel has been scourged, yet the treasure was not betrayed; it has been drowned in the sea, yet the treasure was not shipwrecked: it has died yet the treasure survives.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:314
verses.text: He gave therefore the earnest of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:315
verses.text: Where are they who blaspheme the Spirit's majesty? Give ye heed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:316
verses.text: "He that establisheth us with you in Christ is God who also hath given the earnest of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:317
verses.text: You all know that the earnest is a small part of the whole; let me tell you how.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:318
verses.text: Some one goes to buy a house at a great price; and he says "give me an earnest that I may have confidence: or one goes to take a wife for himself, he arranges about dowry and property, and he says "give me an earnest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:319
verses.text: Observe: in the purchase of a slave and in all covenants there is an earnest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:320
verses.text: Since then Christ made a covenant with us (for He was about to take me as a bride) he also assigned a dowry to me not of money, but of blood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:321
verses.text: But this dowry which He assigns is the bestowal of good things "such as eye hath not seen, and ear hath not heard, neither hath entered into the heart of man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:322
verses.text: He assigned them for the dowry:â€”immortality, praise with the angels, release from death, freedom from sin, the inheritance of a kingdom (so great are his riches), righteousness, sanctification, deliverance from present evils, discovery of future blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:323
verses.text: Great was my dowry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:324
verses.text: Now attend carefully: mark what He does.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:325
verses.text: He came to take the harlot, for so I call her, unclean as she was, that thou mightest understand the love of the bridegroom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:326
verses.text: He came; He took me: He assigns me a dowry: He saith "I give thee my wealth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:327
verses.text: How? "Hast thou lost," He saith, "paradise?" take it back.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:328
verses.text: Hast thou lost thy beauty? take it back; take all these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:329
verses.text: But yet the dowry was not given to me here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:330
verses.text: Observe, this is the reason why He speaks beforehand with reference to this dowry; He warranted to me in the dowry the resurrection of the body,â€”immortality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:331
verses.text: For immortality does not always follow resurrection, but the two are distinct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:332
verses.text: For many have risen, and been again laid low, like Lazarus and the bodies of the saints.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:333
verses.text: But in this case it is not so, but the promise is of resurrection, immortality, a place in the joyful company of angels, the meeting of the Son of Man in the clouds, and the fulfilment of the saying "so shall we ever be with the Lord," the release from death, the freedom from sin, the complete overthrow of destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:334
verses.text: Of what kind is that? "Eye hath not seen nor ear heard neither have entered into the heart of man the things which God hath prepared for them that love Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:335
verses.text: Dost thou give me good things which I know not? He saith "yea; only be espoused to me here, love me in this world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:336
verses.text: "Wherefore dost thou not give me the dowry here?" "It will be given when thou hast come to my Father, when thou hast entered the royal palace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:337
verses.text: Didst thou come to me! nay I came to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:338
verses.text: I came not that thou shouldst abide here but that I might take thee and return.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:339
verses.text: Seek not the dowry here: all depends on hope, and faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:340
verses.text: "And dost thou give me nothing in this world?" He answers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:341
verses.text: "Receive an earnest that thou mayest trust me concerning that which is to come: receive pledges and betrothal gifts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:342
verses.text: Therefore Paul saith "I have espoused you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:343
verses.text: As gifts of betrothal God has given us present blessings: they are an earnest of the future; but the full dowry abides in the other world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:344
verses.text: How so? I will tell you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:345
verses.text: Here I grow old, there I grow not old; here I die, there I die not, here I sorrow, there I sorrow not; here is poverty, and disease, and intrigue, there nothing of that kind exists: here is darkness and light, there is light alone: here is intrigue, there is liberty; here is disease, there is health; here is life which has an end, there is life which hath no end; here is sin, there is righteousness, and sin is banished; here is envy, there nothing of the kind exists.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:346
verses.text: "Give me these things" one says; "Nay! wait in order that thy fellow-servants also may be saved; wait I say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:347
verses.text: He who establisheth us and hath given us the earnest"â€”what kind of earnest? the Holy Spirit, the supply of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:348
verses.text: Let me speak concerning the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:349
verses.text: He gave the signet ring to the Apostles, saying "take this and give it to all".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:350
verses.text: Is the ring then portioned out, and yet not divided? It is so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:351
verses.text: Let me teach you the meaning of the supply of the Spirit: Peter received, and Paul also received the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:352
verses.text: He went about the world, he released sinners from their sins, he restored the lame, he clothed the naked, he raised the dead, he cleansed the lepers, he bridled the devil, he strangled the demons, he held converse with God, he planted a Church, levelled temples to the earth, overturned altars, destroyed vice, established virtue, made angels of men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:353
verses.text: All these things we were.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:354
verses.text: But "the earnest" filled the whole world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:355
verses.text: And when I say the whole I mean all which the sun shines upon, sea, islands, mountains, valleys, and hills.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:356
verses.text: Paul went hither and thither, like some winged creature, with one mouth only contending against the enemy, he the tentmaker, who handled the workman's knife and sewed skins together: and yet this his craft was no hindrance to his virtue, but the tentmaker was stronger than demons, the uneloquent man was wiser than the wise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:357
verses.text: Whence was this? He received the earnest, he bore the signet ring and carried it about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:358
verses.text: All men saw that the King had espoused our nature: the demon saw it and retreated, he saw the earnest, and trembled and withdrew: he saw but the Apostle's garments and fled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:359
verses.text: O the power of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:360
verses.text: He bestowed authority not on the soul, nor on the body, but even on raiment; nor on raiment only but even on a shadow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:361
verses.text: Peter went about and his shadow put diseases to flight, and expelled demons, and raised the dead to life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:362
verses.text: Paul went about the world, cutting away the thorns of ungodliness, sowing broadcast the seeds of godliness, like an excellent ploughman handling the ploughshare of doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:363
verses.text: And to whom did he go? To Thracians, to Scythians, to Indians, to Maurians, to Sardinians, to Goths, to wild savages, and he changed them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:364
verses.text: By what means? By means of "the earnest".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:365
verses.text: How was he sufficient for these things? By the grace of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:366
verses.text: Unskilled, ill-clothed, ill-shod he was upheld by Him "who also hath given the earnest of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:367
verses.text: Therefore he saith "and who is sufficient for these things? But our sufficiency is of God, who hath made us sufficient as ministers of the new Testament, not of the letter but of the Spirit".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:368
verses.text: Behold what the Spirit hath wrought: He found the earth filled with demons and He has made it heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:369
verses.text: For meditate not on present things but review the past in your thought.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:370
verses.text: Formerly there was lamentation, there were altars everywhere, everywhere the smoke and fumes of sacrifice, everywhere unclean rites and mysteries, and sacrifices, everywhere demons holding their orgies, everywhere a citadel of the devil, everywhere fornication decked with wreaths of honour; and Paul stood alone.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:371
verses.text: How did he escape being overwhelmed, or torn in pieces? How could he open his mouth? He entered the Thebaid, and made captives of men, He entered the royal palace, and made a disciple of the king.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:372
verses.text: He entered the hall of judgment, and the judge saith to him "almost thou persuadest me to become a Christian," and the judge became a disciple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:373
verses.text: He entered the prison, and took the jailor captive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:374
verses.text: He visited an island of barbarians, and made a viper the instrument of his teaching.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:375
verses.text: He visited the Romans, and attracted the senate to his doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:376
verses.text: He visited rivers, and desert places in all parts of the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:377
verses.text: There is no land or sea which has not shared in the benefits of his labours; for God has given human nature the earnest of His signet, and when He gives it He saith: some things I give thee now, and others I promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:378
verses.text: Therefore the prophet saith concerning her "The queen did stand upon thy right hand in a vesture woven with gold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:379
verses.text: He does not mean a real vesture, but virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:380
verses.text: Therefore the Scripture elsewhere saith "How camest thou in hither not having a wedding garment?" so that here he does not mean a garment, but fornication, and foul and unclean living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:381
verses.text: As then foul raiment signifies sin, so does golden raiment signify virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:382
verses.text: But this raiment belonged to the king.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:383
verses.text: He Himself bestowed the raiment upon her: for she was naked, naked and disfigured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:384
verses.text: "The queen stood on thy right hand in a vesture woven with gold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:385
verses.text: He is speaking not of raiment but of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:386
verses.text: Observe: the expression itself has great nobility of meaning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:387
verses.text: He does not say "in a vesture of gold" but "in a vesture woven with gold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:388
verses.text: Listen intelligently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:389
verses.text: A vesture of gold is one which is gold throughout: but a vesture woven with gold is one which is partly of gold, partly of silk.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:390
verses.text: Why then did he say that the bride wore not a vesture of gold, but one woven with gold? Attend carefully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:391
verses.text: He means the constitution of the Church in its varied manifestations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:392
verses.text: For since we do not all belong to one condition of life, but one is a virgin, another a widow, a third lives a life of devotionâ€”so the robe of the Church signifies the constitution of the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:393
verses.text: Inasmuch then as our Master knew that if He carved out only one road for us, many must shrink from it, He carved out divers roads.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:394
verses.text: Thou canst not enter the kingdom it may be by the way of virginity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:395
verses.text: Enter it then by the way of single marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:396
verses.text: Canst thou not enter it by one marriage? Perchance thou mayest by means of a second marriage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:397
verses.text: Thou canst not enter by the way of continence: enter then by the way of almsgiving: or thou canst not enter by the way of almsgiving? then try the way of fasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:398
verses.text: If thou canst not use this way, take thatâ€”or if not that, then take this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:399
verses.text: Therefore the prophet spoke not of a garment of gold, but of one woven with gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:400
verses.text: It is of silk, or purple, or gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:401
verses.text: Thou canst not be a golden part? then be a silken one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:402
verses.text: I accept thee, if only thou art clothed in my raiment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:403
verses.text: Therefore also Paul saith "If any man builds upon this foundation, gold, silver, precious stones".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:404
verses.text: Thou canst not be the precious stone? then be the gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:405
verses.text: Thou canst not be the gold? then be the silver, if only thou art resting upon the foundation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:406
verses.text: And again elsewhere, "there is one glory of the sun, and another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:407
verses.text: Thou canst not be a sun? then be a moon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:408
verses.text: Thou canst not be a moon? then be a star.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:409
verses.text: Thou canst not be a large star? be content to be a little one if only thou art in the Heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:410
verses.text: Thou canst not be a virgin? then live continently in the married state, only abiding in the Church.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:411
verses.text: Thou canst not be without possessions? then give alms, only abiding in the Church, only wearing the proper raiment, only submitting to the queen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:412
verses.text: The raiment is woven with gold, it is manifold in texture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:413
verses.text: I do not bar the way against thee: for the abundance of virtues has rendered the dispensation of the king easy in operation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:414
verses.text: "Clothed in a vesture woven with gold, manifold in texture".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:415
verses.text: Her vesture is manifold: unfold, if you please, the deep meaning of the expression here used, and fix your eyes upon this garment woven with gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:416
verses.text: For here indeed some live celibate, others live in an honourable estate of matrimony being not much inferior to them: some have married once, others are widows in the flower of their age.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:417
verses.text: For what purpose is a paradise? and wherefore its variety? having divers flowers, and trees, and many pearls.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:418
verses.text: There are many stars, but only one sun: there are many ways of living, but only one paradise; there are many temples, but only one mother of them all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:419
verses.text: There is the body, the eye, the finger, but all these make up but one man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:420
verses.text: There is the same distinction between the small, the great, and the less.
