verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:421
verses.text: The virgin hath need of the married woman; for the virgin also is the product of marriage, that marriage may not be despised by her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:422
verses.text: The virgin is the root of marriage: thus all things have been linked together, the small with the great, and the great with the small.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:423
verses.text: "The queen did stand on thy right hand clothed in a vesture wrought with gold, manifold in texture".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:424
verses.text: Then follows "Hearken! O daughter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:425
verses.text: The conductor of the bride says that thou art about to go forth from thy home to the home of the bridegroom who in his essential nature far surpasses thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:426
verses.text: I am the conductor of the bride.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:427
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:428
verses.text: Did she immediately become the wife? Yea: for here there is nothing corporeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:429
verses.text: For He espoused her as a wife, He loves her as a daughter, He provides for her as a handmaid, He guards her as a virgin, He fences her round like a garden, and cherishes her like a member: as a head He provides for her, as a root he causes her to grow, as a shepherd He feeds her, as a bridegroom He weds her, as a propitiation He pardons her, as a sheep He is sacrificed, as a bridegroom He preserves her in beauty, as a husband He provides for her support.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:430
verses.text: Many are the meanings in order that we may enjoy a part if it be but a small part of the divine economy of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:431
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter" and behold, and look upon things which are bridal and yet spiritual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:432
verses.text: Hearken O daughter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:433
verses.text: She was at first a daughter of demons, a daughter of the earth, unworthy of the earth and now she has become a daughter of the king.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:434
verses.text: And this He wished who loved her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:435
verses.text: For he who loves does not investigate character: love does not regard uncomeliness: on this account indeed is it called love because it oftentimes hath affection for an uncomely person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:436
verses.text: Thus also did Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:437
verses.text: He saw one who was uncomely (for comely I could not call her) and He loved her, and He makes her young, not having spot or wrinkle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:438
verses.text: Oh what a bridegroom! adorning with grace the ungracefulness of his bride! Hearken O daughter! hearken and behold! Two things He saith "Hearken" and "Behold," two which depend on thyself, one on thy eyes, the other on thy hearing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:439
verses.text: Now since her dowry depended on hearing (and although some of you have been acute enough to perceive this already, let them tarry for those who are feebler: I commend those who have anticipated the truth, and make allowances for those who only follow in their track) since the dowry then depended on hearingâ€”(and what is meant by hearing? faith: for "faith cometh by hearing" faith as opposed to fruition, and actual experience) I said before that He divided the dowry into two, and gave some portion to the bride for an earnest, whilst He promised others in the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:440
verses.text: What did He give her? He gave her forgiveness of sins, remission of punishment, righteousness, sanctification, redemption, the body of the Lord, the divine, spiritual Table, the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:441
verses.text: For all these things the Apostles had.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:442
verses.text: Therefore He gave some parts and promised others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:443
verses.text: Of some there was experience and fruition, others depended upon hope and faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:444
verses.text: Now listen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:445
verses.text: What did He bestow? Baptism and the Sacrifice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:446
verses.text: Of these there is experience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:447
verses.text: What did He promise? Resurrection, immortality of the body, union with angels, a place in the joyful company of archangels, and as a citizen in His kingdom, immaculate life, the good things "which eye hath not seen, nor ear heard nor have entered into the heart of man, things which God hath prepared for them that love Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:448
verses.text: Understand what is said, lest ye lose it: I am labouring to enable you to perceive it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:449
verses.text: The dowry of the bride then was divided into two portions consisting of things present and things to come; things seen and things heard, things given and things taken on trust, things experienced, and things to be enjoyed hereafter; things belonging to present life, and things to come after the resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:450
verses.text: The former things you see, the latter you hear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:451
verses.text: Observe then what He says to her that you may not suppose that she received the former things only, though they be great and ineffable, and surpassing all understanding.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:452
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter and behold;" hear the latter things and behold the former that thou mayest not say "am I again to depend on hope, again on faith, again on the future?" See now: I give some things, and I promise others: the latter indeed depend on hope, but do thou receive the others as pledges, as an earnest, as a proof of the remainder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:453
verses.text: I promise thee a kingdom: and let present things be the ground of thy trust, thy trust in me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:454
verses.text: Dost thou promise me a kingdom? Yea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:455
verses.text: I have given thee the greater part, even the Lord of the kingdom, for "he who spared not his own son, but gave him up for us all, how shall He not with Him also freely give us all things?" Dost thou give me the resurrection of the body? Yea; I have given thee the greater part.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:456
verses.text: What is the nature of it? Release from sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:457
verses.text: How is that the greater part? Because sin brought forth death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:458
verses.text: I have destroyed the parent, and shall I not destroy the offspring? I have dried up the root, and shall I not destroy the produce.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:459
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter and behold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:460
verses.text: What am I to behold? Dead men raised to life, lepers cleansed, the sea restrained, the paralytic braced up into vigour, paradise opened, loaves poured forth in abundance, sins remitted, the lame man leaping, the robber made a citizen of paradise, the publican turned into an evangelist, the harlot become more modest than the maid.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:461
verses.text: Hear and behold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:462
verses.text: Hear of the former things and behold these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:463
verses.text: Accept from present things a proof of the others; concerning those I have given thee pledges, things which are better than they are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:464
verses.text: "What is the meaning of this thy saying?" These things are mine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:465
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter and behold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:466
verses.text: These things are my dower to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:467
verses.text: And what doth the bride contribute? Let us see.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:468
verses.text: What I pray thee dost thou bring that thou mayest not be portionless? What can I, she answers, bring to thee from heathen altars, and the steam of sacrifices and from devils? What have I to contribute? what? sayest thou? Thy will and thy faith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:469
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter and behold".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:470
verses.text: And what wilt thou have me do? "Forget thy own people".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:471
verses.text: What kind of people? the devils, the idols, the sacrificial smoke, and steam, and blood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:472
verses.text: "Forget thy own people, and thy father's house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:473
verses.text: Leave thy father and come after me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:474
verses.text: I left my Father, and came to thee, and wilt thou not leave thy father? But when the word leave is used in reference to the Son do not understand by it an actual leaving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:475
verses.text: What He means is "I condescended, I accommodated myself to thee, I assumed human flesh".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:476
verses.text: This is the duty of the bridegroom, and of the bride, that thou shouldest abandon thy parents, and that we should be wedded to one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:477
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter and behold, and forget thy own people, and thy father's house".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:478
verses.text: And what dost thou give me if I do forget them? "and the king shall desire thy beauty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:479
verses.text: Thou hast the Lord for thy lover.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:480
verses.text: If thou hast Him for thy lover, thou hast also the things which are his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:481
verses.text: I trust ye may be able to understand what is said: for the thought is a subtle one, and I wish to stop the mouth of the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:482
verses.text: Now exert your minds I pray: for whether one hears, or forbears to hear I shall dig and till the soil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:483
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter, and behold, forget also thy own people, and thy father's house, and the king shall desire thy beauty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:484
verses.text: By beauty in this passage the Jew understands sensible beauty; not spiritual but corporeal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:485
verses.text: Attend, and let us learn what corporeal, and what spiritual beauty are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:486
verses.text: There is soul and body: they are two substances: there is a beauty of body, and there is a beauty of soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:487
verses.text: What is beauty of body? an extended eyebrow, a merry glance, a blushing cheek, ruddy lips, a straight neck, long wavy hair, tapering fingers, upright stature, a fair blooming complexion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:488
verses.text: Does this bodily beauty come from nature, or from choice? Confessedly it comes from nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:489
verses.text: Attend that thou mayest learn the conception of philosophers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:490
verses.text: This beauty whether of the countenance, of the eye, of the hair, of the brow, does it come from nature, or from choice? It is obvious that it comes from nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:491
verses.text: For the ungraceful woman, even if she cultivate beauty in countless ways, cannot become graceful in body: for natural conditions are fixed, and confined by limits which they cannot pass over.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:492
verses.text: Therefore the beautiful woman is always beautiful, even if she has no taste for beauty: and the ungraceful cannot make herself graceful, nor the graceful ungraceful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:493
verses.text: Wherefore? because these things come from nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:494
verses.text: Well! thou hast seen corporeal beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:495
verses.text: Now let us turn inwards to the soul: let the handmaid approach the mistress! let us turn I say to the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:496
verses.text: Look upon that beauty, or rather listen to it: for thou canst not see it since it is invisibleâ€”Listen to that beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:497
verses.text: What then is beauty of soul? Temperance, mildness, almsgiving, love, brotherly kindness, tender affection, obedience to God, the fulfilment of the law, righteousness, contrition of heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:498
verses.text: These things are the beauty of the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:499
verses.text: These things then are not the results of nature, but of moral disposition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:500
verses.text: And he who does not possess these things is able to receive them, and he who has them, if he becomes careless, loses them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:501
verses.text: For as in the case of the body I was saying that she who is ungraceful cannot become graceful; so in the case of the soul I say the contrary that the graceless soul can become full of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:502
verses.text: For what was more graceless than the soul of Paul when he was a blasphemer and insulter: what more full of grace when he said "I have fought the good fight, I have finished the course, I have kept the faith".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:503
verses.text: What was more graceless than the soul of the robber? what more full of grace when he heard the words "Verily I say unto thee to-day shalt thou be with me in paradise?" What was more graceless than the publican when he practised extortion? but what more full of grace when he declared his resolution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:504
verses.text: Seest thou that thou canst not alter grace of body, for it is the result not of moral disposition, but of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:505
verses.text: But grace of soul is supplied out of our own moral choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:506
verses.text: Thou hast now received the definition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:507
verses.text: Of what kind are they? that the beauty of the soul proceeds from obedience to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:508
verses.text: For if the graceless soul obeys God it puts off its ungracefulness, and becomes full of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:509
verses.text: "Saul! Saul!" it was said, "why persecutest thou me?" and he replied "and who art Thou Lord?" "I am Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:510
verses.text: And he obeyed, and his obedience made the graceless soul full of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:511
verses.text: Again, He saith to the publican "come follow me" and the publican rose up and became an apostle: and the graceless soul became full of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:512
verses.text: Whence? by obedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:513
verses.text: Again He saith to the fishermen "Come ye after me and I will make you to become fishers of men:" and by their obedience their minds became full of grace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:514
verses.text: Let us see then what kind of beauty He is speaking of here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:515
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter and behold, and forget thy own people and thy father's house, and the king shall desire thy beauty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:516
verses.text: What kind of beauty will he desire? the spiritual kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:517
verses.text: How so? because she is to "forget" He saith "hearken and forget".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:518
verses.text: These are acts of moral choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:519
verses.text: "Hearken!" he said: an ungraceful one hears and her ungracefulness being that of the body is not removed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:520
verses.text: To the sinful woman He has said "Hearken," and if she will obey she sees what manner of beauty is bestowed upon her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:521
verses.text: Since then the ungracefulness of the bride was not physical, but moral (for she did not obey God but transgressed) therefore he leads her to another remedy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:522
verses.text: Thou didst become ungraceful then, not by nature, but by moral choice: and thou didst become full of grace by obedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:523
verses.text: "Hearken O daughter and behold and forget thy own people, and thy father's house, and the king shall desire thy beauty".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:524
verses.text: Then that thou mayest learn that he does not mean anything visible to sense, when thou hearest the word beauty, think not of eye, or nose, or mouth, or neck, but of piety, faith, love, things which are withinâ€”"for all the glory of the king's daughter is from within".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies on Eutropius II 1:525
verses.text: Now for all these things let us offer thanks to God, the giver, for to Him alone belongeth glory, honour, might, for ever and ever, Amen.
